title: How to Survive a Paper Round in the U.K

steps.title: Find a shop / newsagents that has a vacancy for a paper boy/girl.
steps.content: Find a shop / newsagents that has a vacancy for a paper boy/girl. Don't just go to the first one you see. Find out how much they pay, when they will be open and how many papers you will have to deliver on a daily basis. [1] X Research source

steps.title: If you don't live near a suitable shop, inquire at your school to see if anyone in the local area runs a paper business.
steps.content: If you don't live near a suitable shop, inquire at your school to see if anyone in the local area runs a paper business. Sign your name up so even if you don't get one immediately, you'll get one eventually.

steps.title: Make sure you get a work permit from your guidance counselor because if you don't, you'll be classed as breaking the law.
steps.content: Make sure you get a work permit from your guidance counselor because if you don't, you'll be classed as breaking the law. A guidance counselor, parent, or a guardian should give their permission if applicable. [2] X Trustworthy Source Official UK government website Official website for the public sector of the UK government Go to source

steps.title: Learn your route like the back of your hand.
steps.content: Learn your route like the back of your hand. Learn the easiest and quickest way around all the homes and businesses you need to deliver to. Ensure you know which street, lanes and roads are where because being lost is one of the worst things that can happen. Ensure you deliver on time because if you're late, you might not get as much pay.

steps.title: If it is a long round consider taking a bike.
steps.content: If it is a long round consider taking a bike. If the houses are all next to each other then don't bother, unless you want to. However it goes quicker with a bike. [3] X Trustworthy Source Official UK government website Official website for the public sector of the UK government Go to source

steps.title: Get prepared the night before.
steps.content: Get prepared the night before. If you had to be there at 7:00 a.m. get up at 6:00 to 6:15. [4] X Research source Have something to eat before you go. Something like a banana and a glass of water. [5] X Research source This gives you enough energy and hydration to keep you going.

steps.title: Be prepared for the weather.
steps.content: Be prepared for the weather. If it's cold, wear a warm coat or suitable jacket. This is the most important thing. Make sure it is waterproof. The worst thing that can happen is that you get soaked to the bone or covered in snow. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Have lights if it's dark.
steps.content: Have lights if it's dark. It will mostly be cold and dark, unless it is between March and September. Put lights on your bike, it's the law, and carry a torch. Keep your bike in full working order and cycle safely.

steps.title: Wear a high visibility jacket or fluorescent arm bands.
steps.content: Wear a high visibility jacket or fluorescent arm bands. You may look silly but you'd be bloody terrified going down a busy road when cars don't expect you to be there and they can't see you. It's really not worth the risk. And besides, who's going to know? Put on suitable shoes too. You may have a long walk. If it's icy, try to wear shoes or boots that give you some grip. Remember pavements and drives won't be gritted.

steps.title: Try to be safety conscious.
steps.content: Try to be safety conscious. It's dark, often, you are alone, and possibly wandering around isolated farm houses or down unlit driveways. Have a mobile phone with you if possible. Don't accept lifts back home from strangers, or cups of tea from customers you don't know, however cold it is. Make sure that you are usually finished and home around the same time so people know to look for you if you are delayed, if your bike got a puncture for example.

steps.title: Be friendly but not familiar if you meet a homeowner you deliver to.
steps.content: Be friendly but not familiar if you meet a homeowner you deliver to. Say good morning. It might help you earn a tip at Christmas.

steps.title: Note that weekend rounds are by far the hardest in the week.
steps.content: Note that weekend rounds are by far the hardest in the week. The papers are heavy with supplements and you'll probably need to take your time and split the round into two bags. That only really matters if you have a seven day round. Week days are the lightest.
